Shell Script to Open Files related a git commit

25 Sep 2020

This is a small shell script that I use to open all files related to a commit in git; I find it quite useful when I want to resume working on a local branch.

Side note: I don't use an IDE (I haven't found one that I can live with, although I use Qt Creator from time to time, mainly for its code parsing capabilities (the "Follow symbol under cursor" is a must when reading/exploring code)). However for my day-to-day usage I like using Kate, familiarity is important, I started coding using Kate and Konsole, I am sticking with them for the time being.

Anyway, let's get to the script.

#!/bin/bash
gitPrefix=$(git rev-parse --show-toplevel)

__num=$(git diff --name-only | wc -l)

filter_open() {
    $1 | perl -p -e 's!.+!'$gitPrefix'/$&!; s!.+(png|jpeg)$!!' | xargs kate -n > /dev/null 2>&1 &
}

if [ -z "$1" -a "$__num" -ge 1 ]; then
    filter_open "git diff --name-only"
else
    filter_open "git diff HEAD^1 --name-only"
fi

git rev-parse --show-toplevel: returns the absolute path to the topelevel git repo directory

git diff --name-only: returns the list of the files that are changed but not commited yet

git diff HEAD^1 --name-only: returns the list of files that were changed (committed or not) since the commit before last in the repo

perl -p -e 's!.+!'$gitPrefix'/$&!; s!.+(png|jpeg)$!!': since the git difff commands above return relative paths, I need to prepend $gitPrefix (the output of the git rev-parse --show-toplevel command) to all those relative paths, that's what this perl command does; also it filters out all png/jpeg files (I don't want to edit images with a text editor... it doesn't work)

As you can see, I write hacky bash scripts, I am sure there are ways to make it more elegant, but it works, so.

I have two use cases here:

  • I started working in a branch, and haven't committed anything yet, so to reopen all the files I've changed in kate, I use the script without any arguments
  • I started working on a branch, committed some stuff, then worked some more but haven't committed that work-in-progress yet, if I want to open all files (those that have been committed in the last commit and those that are still not committed), I call the script with any argument e.g. all.

    • Bonus point, if you save the script as e.g. git-open-files somewhere in your PATH, you can call the script directly (after making it executable) from terminal or you can use it as a git command, i.e. git open-files should work.

    Happy hacking!

    Credits: I had done some online research to get most of those commands (I find it easier to search for a "concept", the after actually finding it, then read the relevant sections of the man pages; sometimes (well, usually) someone, somewhere, had already asked the same question :)), so thanks to all those online resources; e.g. I definitely recall finding the git rev-parse --show-toplevel command in a stack{overflow,extachage} thread.
